Subgraph Coverage Patterns

Pattern mining from Graph Transactional Data ({' '}GTD{' '}) is an active area of research with applications in the domains of bioinformatics, chemical informatics and social networks.{' '}Existing works address the problem of mining frequent subgraphs from GTD.{' '}However,{' '}the knowledge concerning the coverage aspect of a set of subgraphs is also valuable for improving the performance of several applications.

Definition

Given a graph transactional dataset and user defined constraints {show_modal_with_def("minrf")}} className="def">minimum Relative Frequency{' '}({' '}minRF{' '}){' '},{' '}{show_modal_with_def("mincs")}} className="def">minimum Coverage Support{' '}({' '}minCS{' '}) and {show_modal_with_def("maxor")}} className="def">maximum Overlap Ratio{' '}({' '}maxOR{' '}),{' '}a set of subgraphs say SP {' '}is called Subgraph Coverage Pattern if Coverage Support of SP {">="} minCS and Relative Frequency of SP{' '} {">="} minRF and Overlap Ratio {"<="} maxOR.

Coverage Support

Given Graph Transactional Dataset D and a subgraph pattern SP,{' '}the coverage support of SP ({' '}CSg (SP, D){' '}) is the percentage of graph transactions in D covered by at least one subgraph in SP .

Here, 0 CSg (SP, D) 1

CSg (SP, D) = 1 when all of the graph transactions in D are covered by SP . Conversely, CSg (SP, D) = 0 when none of the graph transactions are covered by SP.A pattern SP is interesting with respect to coverage point of view if CSg (SP, D) minCSg , where minCS g is a userdefined minimum Coverage Support threshold for graph transactions.

Example
Fig. 1: Formula for Coverage Support of a Subgraph Pattern SP in D
Fig. 2: (a) Sample of 10 graph transactions, (b) Candidate subgraphs with minRF g =0.2.

Consider graph transactional dataset D comprising of 10 graph transactions G1 to G10 , shown in Figure 2(a). Three subgraphs S1 , S2 and S3 are shown in Figure 2(b). Let Subgraph Pattern SP = {"{"} S1,S2,3 {"}"} .Here, S1 is a subgraph of G1, G6 and G10 ; S2 is a subgraph of G5 , G7 and G8 ; and S3 is a subgraph of G4 and G7 . The subgraph S1 is said to cover G1 since S1 G1 . Hence, cover(S1 , G1 )=1. Moreover, |CSet(SP , D)| / |D| = |{"{"}G1 ,G 6 ,G 10{"}"} {"{"}G5 ,G7,G 8 {"}"} {"{"}G4 ,G 7{"}"} | = 8 /10 = 0.8.

Relative Frequency of a Subgraph

Given Graph Transactional Data D and a subgraph Sj , we denote the percentage of graph transactions in D covered by Sj as Relative Frequency. Formula for computing Relative Frequency of Subgraph Sj in D is shown in figure 1.

Here, 0 RFg (Sj ,D) 1. We can extract subgraphs of interest from D based on user-specified minRFg threshold.

Example
Fig. 1: Formula for Relative Frequency of Subgraph Sj in D
Fig. 2: (a) Sample of 10 graph transactions, (b) Candidate subgraphs with minRF g =0.2

Consider graph transactional dataset D comprising of 10 graph transactions G1 to G10 , shown in Figure 2(a). Three subgraphs S1 , S2 and S3 are shown in Figure 2(b). Here, S1 is a subgraph of G1, G6 and G10 ; S2 is a subgraph of G5 , G7 and G8 ; and S3 is a subgraph of G4 and G7 . The subgraph S1 is said to cover G1 since S1 G1 . Hence, cover(S1 , G1 )=1. Moreover, CSet(S1 , D) = {"{G"}1 ,G 6 ,G 10 and RFg (S1 , D) = |Cset(S1)|/D = 3/10 = 0.3. Similarly RF values of S2 , S3 are 0.3 and 0.2 respectively

Overlap Ratio of a Pattern X

Let X = {"{"}Op , Oq ,. . . , Or , Os {"}"} be a pattern such that RF (Op ) RF (Oq) RF (Or ) RF (Os). (Here, the notations Op , Oq , Or, and Os represent Subgraph IDs.) The overlap ratio of a pattern X is defined as the ratio of the number of transactions common in CSet(X {"{"}Os{"}"}) and CSet(Os) to CSet(Os).It is defined as shown in figure 1.

For a pattern X, 0 OR(X) 1

A pattern X is interesting if OR(X) maxOR, where maxOR is a user-defined maximum OR threshold.

Example
Fig. 1: Formula for Overlap Ratio of a pattern X.
Fig. 2: (a) Sample of 10 graph transactions, (b) Candidate subgraphs with minRF g =0.2

Consider graph transactional dataset D comprising of 10 graph transactions G1 to G10 , shown in Figure 2(a). Three subgraphs S1 , S2 and S3 are shown in Figure 2(b). Let Subgraph Pattern SP = {"{"} S1,S2,3 {"}"} .Here, S1 is a subgraph of G1, G6 and G10 ; S2 is a subgraph of G5 , G7 and G8 ; and S3 is a subgraph of G4 and G7 . The subgraph S1 is said to cover G1 since S1 G1 . Hence, cover(S1 , G1 )=1. Moreover, |CSet(SP , D)| / |D| = |{"{"}G1 ,G 6 ,G 10{"}"} {"{"}G5 ,G7,G 8 {"}"} {"{"}G4 ,G 7{"}"} | = 8 /10 = 0.8.

Example
Fig. 1: (a) Sample of 10 graph transactions, (b) Candidate subgraphs with minRF g =0.2

Figure 1.a of above image is the Graph Transactional Dataset consisting of 10 graphs.{' '}In Figure 2(b),{' '}let SP be the set {"{ S1, S2, S3 }"}.{' '}The RF values of S1,{' '}S2 and S3 are 0.3,{' '}0.3 and 0.2 respectively.{' '}The coverage set of SP,{' '}CSet({' '}SP,{' '}D{' '}){' '}= {' '}{"{ G1, G4, G5, G6, G7, G8, G10 }"}.{' '}The coverage support of SP,{' '}CS{g} (SP, D) = |{' '}CSet(SP,D){' '}| / |D| = 7/10 = 0.7.{' '}The multiset of transactions covered by pattern SP,{' '}M({' '}SP, D{' '}){' '}= {' '}{"{ ( G1, G6, G10 ), ( G5, G7, G8 ), ( G4, G7 ) }"}. Therefore, the overlap among transactions covered by subgraphs of SP ,overlap{g}{' '}({' '}SP, D{' '}) = ({' '}|{' '}M (SP,D){' '}|{' '}/{' '}|{' '}CSet({' '}SP,D{' '}){' '}|{' '}){' '}-{' '}1 = (8/7)-1 = 0.142.{' '}Given the values of minRF{g} = 0.2, minCS{g} = 0.7 and maxO{g} = 0.5, the pattern SP = {"{ S1, S2, S3 }"} is an SCP.

SIFT Framework

Subgraph ID based Flat Transactional{' '}({' '}SIFT{' '}){' '}framework is generalized in the sense that it extracts all potential SCPs from GTD subject to user-specified thresholds of relative frequency, coverage support and overlap.The framework consists of three parts for extracting SCPs from Graph Transactional Dataset. 

                       1.
For extracting subgraphs from D, which satisfies the minRFg constraint, an existing subgraph discovery algorithm, such as gSpan can be employed. We construct the database of {" "} as the output , where SID is a Subgraph Identifier and Clabe is minimum DFS code assigned as canonical label to subgraph. 

                       2.
Second, with the database of {""} as the input, we form the SID-based flat transactional dataset, where each SID-based flat transaction consists of all SIDs of subgraphs corresponding graph transaction. In this step, we map SIDs to corresponding graph transaction identifier (GID) and form the database of {" "} as the output. This forms the SID- based flat transactional dataset. 

                       3.
Third, after forming the SID-based flat transactional dataset, the problem of extracting candidate SCPs becomes the problem of extracting coverage patterns. Therefore, we can employ an existing coverage pattern mining algorithm to extract SCPs. For efficient extraction of SCPs, we employ a pruning heuristic related to overlap and efficiently extract SCPs subject to the minCSg and minOg constraints.
